s: Beginnings, conception, dawn, eternal ... vitality and creativity. The Morninglord was symbolized by the rising sun, but rather than being the god of the sun itself, he was the god of dawn, which represented the potential of a new day....

t: Morninglord | Forgotten Realms Wiki | Fandom
s: Morninglords, formerly known as morninglords of Lathander, were the specialty priests of the deity Lathander,[3] considered to be among the most elite orders, as well as one of the highest ranks, within his clergy members.[4] These respected priests served as dedicated healers and councilors ...

t: Lathander - bg3.wiki
s: April 9, 2025 - The Morninglord is the god of the dawn and spring, of birth and beginnings. He is invoked to christen both new ventures and new life. His followers embrace growth and renewal, and despise the undead.

t: The Morninglord - Mistipedia
s: He is venerated by the Cult of the Morninglord[1], a mostly Barovian faith that originated with visions of a Faerunian outlander named Martyn Pelkar[2], known commonly as Martyn the Mad.[1] He believed he was saved from vampires by the Morninglord, whom forced them to spare the boy.

D&D: An Adventurer's Guide to Lathander – The Morninglord - Bell of Lost Souls
s: March 3, 2024 - Lathander, as he is known, is a benevolent deity. The Morninglord is a deity of creativity, dawn, renewal, birth, athletics, spring, self-perfection, vitality, and youth. Like many gods of light, Lathander abhors the undead.

t: Morninglord Character in Barovia | World Anvil
s: The main god of worship in Barovia. His holy symbol is depicted as a rising sun. Most Barovians pray daily for the Morninglord to save them from their torment, but the skies have remained cloudy and dark for over 700 years.
